utterances: So what is it that could account for this?
What kind of social factors?
It has to do with time and resources of stimulation of parents towards the child.
So basically the first one gets kind of the undivided attention of the parents for a while until the second one comes along.
And then it's all over.
It's not all over.
But it has to be shared.
But you're right about that.
IQ tests are notoriously culturally biased.
Yes.
Can you really deduce then just through IQ tests whether the oldest sibling is indeed objectively smarter than the youngest?
I would not believe this to be a problem comparing siblings or comparing young men approximately at the same time in the same society.
There are, of course, famous smart people who were younger siblings - Charles Darwin, Rene Descartes, Bill Gates...
Yes.
What does that say?
Well, you see, this birth order effect is quite small.
But it has probably some impact on the population level.
If all other things were equal, a mean difference of two IQ units would have some impact, whereas on the individual level it would not mean almost anything.
It would have almost no predictive power in an individual setting.
We looked at more than 60,000 brother pairs, one elder, one younger.
And when they had different scores in the IQ test, it would be a 57 percent probability that the best one would be the eldest.
But there is still 43 percent probability that the youngest is the better.
So you see, on the individual level it's very dangerous to say that it automatically has to be the eldest that is the smarter.
Except in my case.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
I'm not the eldest myself, so that's why I stress this point.
I see.
My older brother is very pleased with this study, I can tell you.
Yeah, yeah.
And you only studied men, right?
But this would hold true for women as well?
Well, I have to rely then on the other studies and there seems to be very little difference concerning this birth order effect; it's therefore women as well.
Okay, well, thank you very much.
Okay, thank you.
That's Dr. Petter Kristensen, the lead author of a new study that shows higher IQ points for children who were born first.
(Soundbite of music)
More smart stuff coming up on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
The group Take 6 pulls from all sorts of American singing traditions.
There's gospel, some doo-wop and a lot of jazz.
But even with all those influences, no other group is quite like this a cappella sextet.
They've been shaping their sounds since the mid-1980s when college friends Claude McKnight and Mark Kibble founded the group.
Over the last two decades, they've worked with greats like Quincy Jones, Al Jarreau and Joe Sample, just to name a few.
McKnight and Kibble joined me earlier, and Kibble says he never dreamed he'd be in a group with some of the guys he grew up with.
At the age of 19, she was deployed to Iraq.
The experiences of the war, especially the sounds, followed her home.
One day a car backfired on the freeway.

Now, the issue of race has come up, probably, you know, maybe it was a mistake at first but has been escalated by both sides, especially the thing on the Hillary side, with that comment by yesterday of Bob Johnson, the president of BET, Black Entertainment Television, who basically made a not-so-veiled criticism of Barack Obama's drug use.
And it's just gotten ugly.

And unfortunately for John Edwards, he recently lost in the shuffle because, for all the things he has to say, he's not getting any headlines or much media play because the media seems to be so focused on this.
And the other aspect of the campaign, obviously, you said, initially, he'd focus on Iowa.
What about fundraising?
How was he doing there?
Well, he's not doing well.
Of course, as I mentioned, both Obama and Clinton have raised over a hundred million dollars each.
John Edwards now has to take - has agreed to take federal matching funds because he can't - does not have the open checkbooks that the other two candidates have.
And so question, of course, is whether he can be competitive.
I mean, far beyond us to be writing anybody off.
And I think, you know, that we made that mistake before in New Hampshire, as the polls showed you.

But somehow, with 22 states, that stake on February 5th alone, John Edwards is going to have to win somewhere, hopefully for his sake, maybe South Carolina is his best opportunity because, otherwise, it's very hard to compete in so many states with so many expensive media market.
The other contest coming up soon is the caucus - the Democratic caucus in Nevada.
Right.
That's on Saturday, and that's where Barack Obama's campaigning today.
John Edwards seems to be spending more time in South Carolina where he's doing better in the polls.
And then, of course, you know, after that, it's, it's really on to Super Tuesday.
Nobody - the Democrats are not involved in Tuesday's primary, tomorrow's primary in Michigan.
They are staying out of the state.
Hillary Clinton's name is on the ballot in Michigan.
Both Barack Obama and John Edwards supporters are hoping that the Democrats will vote for an uncommitted slate to, so Hillary Clinton won't get all the delegates.
We're expecting Senator Edwards to join us shortly.
He's on the campaign trail and I gather, talking to a lot of media organizations today.
Again, if you'd like to join the conversation, give us a call, 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK.
Again, the e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
And we're just waiting for Senator Edwards' line to be cleared in the studio.
Ken?
You know, there's one thing I also — the question is whether he helps or hurts Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton by staying in the race, given the fact that he says he's a candidate for change.
Barack Obama's saying he's a candidate for change.
And the fact that Edwards sees Hillary Clinton as a candidate of the status quo, one could make the argument that by staying in the race, he, perhaps, helps Hillary Clinton.
The change vote is split among the two of them, and Hillary Clinton benefits.
Well, John Edwards joins us now by phone from Pawleys Island in South Carolina.
Senator Edwards, nice to have you back on TALK OF THE NATION.
Thanks.
Wonderful to be with you.
And we all heard you after the primary in New Hampshire, saying you're in it all the way and you expect to be the Democratic nominee.
So, we're not going to ask you that sort of tactical question that Ken was talking about.
But a lot of people look ahead to South Carolina, the state you won the last time around.
Is this — how important is this to you?
It's important.
South Carolina's important.
Nevada's important.
But, you know, we've had two states vote out of 50, and both those states are early, and they'll affect what comes after.
But as you just pointed out, I'm in this for the long haul so I'm looking — in fact, later this week I go to Nevada from South Carolina.
And then later this week, I go to several February-5th states.
So this is going to be a long-term contest between the three of us.
So it's not to make or break in South Carolina?
It is not.
I don't think it is for any of us.
And indeed, some people in South Carolina have been asking questions, why is he going to Nevada and to some of the February-5th states.
You need to stay here.
Oh, but I need to do well in South Carolina, but I need to do well in Nevada and all those that will do compete in the February-5th states.
But I've been, you know, I've been through this process before - seasoned at it.
I know what it takes.
And this is going to go on for a long time.
And everybody's going to be — well, voters, I think we've had too much in America of people's voices not being heard.

And what I want to make sure - and I think the other two candidates feel the same way - is that America gets to speak on this issue, of who's going to be the Democratic nominee, not just a few states.
Do you have a preference between your two main rivals?
Yeah, I have a preference.
And you're talking to the preference.
I don't know if that's a preference between them.
I have a preference that I believe that what America needs is we do need change.
But we need somebody who will unite America around that change and will stand up and fight the entrenched interests that are preventing the change — oil companies, drug companies, et cetera.
We want to give listeners a chance to ask you questions, too.
So let's go to Juan(ph).
And Juan's with us from Long Island in New York.
Hello, gentlemen.
John Edwards, it's a privilege to speak with you.
Thanks.
It's nice to speak with you.
My question for you is, I've noticed that Barack Obama's message sounds, in many ways, similar to yours.
What are you doing to differentiate yourself from him?
